document.docAuthor: Pereira-Colavite, Alessandre & De, Claudio J. B.
document.masterDocTitle: Taxonomy of Neomuscina Townsend (Diptera, Muscidae) from Brazil

mods:titleInfo.mods:title: Taxonomy of Neomuscina Townsend (Diptera, Muscidae) from Brazil

paragraph.treatmentCitationGroup:
Muscina zosteris Shannon
& del
Ponte 1926
: 579
(description, original designation).

Neomuscina zosteris
Shannon and Del Ponte 1928
: 142
(listed, new combination), 146 (key);
Séguy 1937
: 350
(catalogue);
Snyder 1949
: 4
(key), 8 (redescription), 10 (comment “possibly the same as
Mydaea sparsiplumata Stein
”);
Snyder 1954
: 424
(key), 427 (comments);
Pont 1972
: 51
(catalogue); de
Carvalho et al . 1993
: 61
(catalogue); Couri & de
Carvalho 2002
: 150
–152 (key);
Costacurta et al . 2003
: 394
(collected); Couri & de Carvalho 2005 : 9 (listed); de Carvalho et al . 2005 : 99 (catalogue);
Rodríguez-Fernández et al . 2006
: 98
(listed).

Neomuscina fulvifrons
Snyder 1949
: 5
(key), 20 (description);
Snyder 1954
: 427
(synonymized with
N. zosteris
).

caption.paragraph:
FIGURES 127–132.
Neomuscina zosteris
. Male terminalia: 127. Fifth sternite, dorsal view; 128. Epandrium, surstylus and cercal plate, lateral view; 129. Epandrium, surstylus and cercal plate, posterior view; 130. Aedeagus, lateral view. Female terminalia: 131. Dorsal view; 132. Ventral view. (Scale 0.5 mm)

subSubSection.paragraph: Diagnosis : acrostichal 0: 1 or 1 : 1 ; dorsocentral 2 : 4 ; mid femur with two preapical setae; hind tibia with one submedian anterodorsal seta; wing hyaline, with dark cloud on r-m; calypters with darkened borders; female: with more than one row of dorsal setae between segments VI and VII.
Male . Length. Body: 3.3–4.5 mm ; wing: 5.6–6.7 mm .

Head : eyes separated from each other by 0.08–0.14 mm , at level of ocellar tubercle; 14–15 pairs of frontal setae; ocellar seta large and parallel; postocellar seta large and divergent; inner vertical seta small and convergent; outer vertical seta small and divergent.

Thorax : acrostichal 0: 1 or 1 : 1 (some males may have a very weak second pair, with acrostichal 2 : 1 ); dorsocentral 2 : 4 ; intra-alars 2 ; fore tibia with distinct submedian anterodorsal setae; apex of fore tibia with setae on dorsal, posterodorsal, posteroventral and ventral surfaces; mid femur with row of setae on posteroventral and anteroventral surfaces from base to middle, reappearing near apex; mid femur with two preapical setae, on posterodorsal and posterior surfaces; apex of mid tibia with setae on anterior, anterodorsal, dorsal, posterodorsal, posterior, ventral and anteroventral surfaces; hind femur with complete row of dorsal and anteroventral setae, and row of posteroventral setae from base to middle; hind tibia with one submedian anterodorsal seta and two submedian anteroventral setae; hind tibia with anterior, anterodorsal, dorsal, and anteroventral setae at apex; wing with one dorsal and one or two ventral setae at apex of stem vein.

Female (differing as follows): Length. Body: 5.6–6.1 mm ; wing: 5.8–6.4 mm ; eyes separated from each other by 0.26–0.32 mm , at level of ocellar tubercle; eight pairs of frontal convergent setae, except for upper two pairs, divergent; ocellar and postocellar setae large and divergent; inner vertical seta large and convergent, and outer vertical seta large and divergent; two rows of dorsal setae between segments VI and VII; sternite VIII with strong spike-like setae; epiproct with four setae, setae in a square-shaped arrangement ( 2 : 2 ).

Comments : The acrostichal setae of
N. zosteris
are very variable. As indicated by
Snyder ( 1954 )
, both males and females may have acrostichal setae 0: 1 or 1 : 1 , the presence of the anterior pair being more common in males. We have identified a weak, second anterior pair in a few individuals. However, the dissection and examination of the terminalia (n = 4 ) did not indicate that those individuals belong to a different species and we believe that this second anterior pair of acrosticals is a variation within the species. Based on the description provided by Stein,
Snyder ( 1949 )
suspected that
Mydaea sparsiplumata Stein
(=
N. sparsiplumata
[ syntypes : NMW , ZMHB ]) could be conspecific with
N. zosteris
. However, until the two type-species are examined, both should be held separately.
Neomuscina ponti
appears to be quite similar to
N. zosteris
.

Syntypes
(not examined): USNM (?). Type-locality: Tucumán, Argentina .

Material examined: BRAZIL . Minas Gerais.
